channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Cruise into this Dreamy Career. Perl role in Malta
item.description: These adaptable folks are an international company who pride themselves on making online trading a breeze. After twenty-plus years cruising the financial waters, they’re subject matter experts who provide a stable, engaging environment for their crew. Located in glorious Malta, they offer a supportive team that believes in open communication and solving problems together.

item.title: Is your Python as good as your Perl? Perl/Python role in London
item.description: Our client is at the pinnacle of the premium native advertising game for corporate, tech, financial services, and lifestyle technology. This role is for a Senior Developer who is equally comfortable with Perl AND Python.

item.title: Good (Perl) Humans Wanted. Remote Perl role in USA
item.description: Working with first responders, educators, manufacturers, and engineers, our client is the leading provider of award-winning intelligent SaaS solutions. To help them keep doing that, they’re looking for a Perl developer with Catalyst and DBlx::Class.

item.title: Remote and ready to run. Remote Perl role in UK
item.description: Fueled by passion, these self-starters don’t require a lot of supervision, and they’re looking for the same from you. In addition to the ability to stay on task, you’ll have experience writing high quality Perl, HTML, JavaScript, and CSS. SQL and DBlx::Class is your bread and butter. If you enjoy writing your own tools using Perl, Bash, HTML, CSS, and JS, this is the role for you.

item.title: Spring has sprung, the grass has riz… Remote Perl Role with UK and EU
item.description: Your day-to-day includes working with internet and development tech, web services, unit testing, and code review. You’ll work with the customer support team to respond to issues, implement new microservices, and squash bugs in Perl web applications and backend systems. You’ll be equally at home with Modern Object Oriented and legacy Perl.

item.title: Boston Perl Mongers Online Meeting - topic TBD or round-table
item.description: Tuesday April 12th, 2021 07:00 PM Eastern Time (US and Canada)

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: It's a primathon!
item.description: Short and simple blog, with to the point discussion. Thank you for your support as always.

item.title: Prime Cuban Additives
item.description: Modular solutions in Raku is very compact and easy to follow. Keep it up great work.

item.title: All about primes
item.description: We have been provided multiple versions of the task. Thank you for sharing the knowledge with us.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 158
item.description: Luis is once again came up with one-liner in Perl. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 158: to be prime or not to be prime
item.description: Raku one-liner for Additive Primes task is really cool. Thank you for all the support.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 158: Additive Primes and Cuban Primes
item.description: The joy of getting the taste of Perl and Raku in one place. It has been source of great knowledge for years. Thanks for everything.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge 158
item.description: Performance analytics is the main attraction. I appreciate the hard work put in every week. Thanks for sharing the knowledge with us.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 158
item.description: Cool one-liner in Raku is the highlight for me. The explanation makes it so easy to follow. Keep it up great work.

item.title: PWC158 - First Series Cuban Primes
item.description: Flavio has been sharing Perl and Raku magic every week. Thank you for being great support.

item.title: PWC158 - Additive Primes
item.description: Don't you like 'The questions' section? I liked it personally. Raku one-liners is really cool. Thanks for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: In Our Primes
item.description: Short and precise task analysis with catch blog title as always. Thanks for everything.

item.title: Cubans In Their Prime
item.description: I liked the discussion of task much better than the Wikipedia definition. It makes it so easy to follow. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Add Another Prime to the Pile
item.description: The task analysis is main attraction for me as always. Solution in Raku is very catchy too. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Cuban Addition, Primarily with Raku
item.description: Optimisation of solution is highlight of the week. Also the explanation of key features of Raku is too good. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 154
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 158
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Additive Primes" and "First Series Cuban Primes" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 159
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Farey Sequence" and "Moebius Number". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Split a PDF into individual pages
item.description: Great use of PDF::API2 to split a pdf. Nice working example.

item.title: Email::Stuffer
item.description: A nice introduction to Email::Stuffer.

item.title: Possible security problem in CPAN modules / Zlib CVE-2018-25032
item.description: zlib has a major flaw and bug discovered as CVE-2018-25032. It is known to cause denial-of-service attacks.

item.title: First impression of "use standard"
item.description: Nice introduction to "standard" feature of Perl. Well written blog explaining the nitty-gritty.

item.title: Making Dynamically Required Package Names More Discoverable in Perl
item.description: Best demo of perlimports and how to deal with edge cases. Highly Recommended.

item.title: #558 - Perl Magic
item.description:
Hi there,

I wish you all very Happy Ramadan. May ALLAH s.w.t. bless us all in the holy month.

Have you seen Perl code that surprised you recently?

I have, only recently, found out braces become optional when calling subroutine depending when you call the subroutine. If the subroutine is defined before you call in the script then it is optional. And if you call the subroutine and later in the script you define the subroutine, which is perfect too, then braces are must.

How about this calling sub add() passing two scalar parameters? add my ($x, $y) = (2, 3);

I came across blog post by Olaf Alders where he shares very interesting use of '::' in package name.

Enjoy rest of the newsletter.
